cluster_classes.class_label: Butterfly Host Plants and Oviposition Sites
cluster_classes.class_description: Host plants and their structures (e.g., leaves, undersides of leaves) that serve as oviposition sites and food sources for butterfly eggs, larvae, and chrysalides.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Plants and their leaves used for egg-laying and larval feeding in the butterfly life cycle.

members.entity_description: Plant leaves that serve as sites for egg-laying, feeding by caterpillars, and attachment for chrysalis formation.
Specific plants on which female butterflies deposit their eggs and that serve as food sources and habitat for early butterfly life stages.
The lower surface of plant leaves where butterfly eggs are commonly laid.

cluster_classes.class_description: Predators of butterfly eggs and larvae and the use of leaf undersides and similar behaviors to reduce predation risk.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Eggs laid on the underside of leaves to protect them from predators.

members.entity_description: The lower surface of plant leaves where butterfly eggs are commonly laid.
Animals that might eat or harm butterfly eggs on leaves.

cluster_classes.class_description: Organisms that prey on butterflies (birds, reptiles, and other insects) and the ecological role of butterflies as prey within food webs.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Butterflies also serve as a food source for birdsâ€¦ Birds are listed as predators that eat butterflies.

members.entity_description: The ecological role of butterflies as prey for birds, reptiles, and other insects.
Vertebrate animals that consume butterflies as part of their diet.
Cold-blooded vertebrates identified as predators that eat butterflies.
Insect species besides butterflies that prey on butterflies as food.

args.new_name: Butterfly Predators, Prey Role, and Predation Risk
args.new_description: Predators of butterflies and their eggs/larvae (birds, reptiles, other insects, and unspecified predators), the ecological role of butterflies as prey within food webs, and behaviors/locations such as egg-laying on leaf undersides that reduce predation risk.
args.justification: ClsC_51c702f9 and ClsR_85e5cf63 both focus on butterfly predation (predators and butterflies as prey), with overlapping scope where one covers predators and anti-predator use of leaf undersides and the other covers specific predator taxa and prey role, so they should be a single coherent predation/predation-risk class.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology: Host Plants, Predators & Anti-predator Strategies
args.justification: ClsC_ac18d27f (host plants and oviposition sites) is ecologically coupled to the predation/predation-risk classes via egg-laying and concealment on leaf undersides, so assigning a shared, broader class_group better connects host-plant and predation interactions in a single butterfly ecology group.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology: Host Plants, Predators & Anti-predator Strategies
args.justification: The newly merged predation-focused class and the host-plant class describe complementary aspects of butterfly ecology (prey role, predators, and oviposition-site concealment), so they should share a unified class_group to reflect this higher-level ecological connection.

executed_decisions.justification: ClsC_51c702f9 and ClsR_85e5cf63 both focus on butterfly predation (predators and butterflies as prey), with overlapping scope where one covers predators and anti-predator use of leaf undersides and the other covers specific predator taxa and prey role, so they should be a single coherent predation/predation-risk class.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology: Host Plants, Predators & Anti-predator Strategies
executed_decisions.justification: ClsC_ac18d27f (host plants and oviposition sites) is ecologically coupled to the predation/predation-risk classes via egg-laying and concealment on leaf undersides, so assigning a shared, broader class_group better connects host-plant and predation interactions in a single butterfly ecology group.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology: Host Plants, Predators & Anti-predator Strategies
executed_decisions.justification: The newly merged predation-focused class and the host-plant class describe complementary aspects of butterfly ecology (prey role, predators, and oviposition-site concealment), so they should share a unified class_group to reflect this higher-level ecological connection.
